body: @himanshug I wrote this today based on the debugging steps I used in #2500 . Also since the other PR needs consistency between 0.9.0 and master, I don't want to expand the scope of that PR to more than whats needed.
ok, i will soon make that change in a PR then.
It would be great to add this to the docs should I file a separate docs issue?
@CHOIJAEHONG1, @vogievetsky makes a good point. We should have some docs for this

I like it as an interface (they just seem cleaner to me when reviewing classes written by others- no need to verify that the base impl actually makes sense in the subclass). But if we are gonna do that, we better do it fast as it would be backwards incompatible and would need to either make it into 0.9.0 or wait for 0.10.0.

Fwiw I am also okay with leaving it the way it is, if people think it is too much of a hassle to change or just plain not worth it.

maybe we can discuss at the dev sync next tuesday.
@fjy / @gianm this is why some of the builds seemed to succeed but report failures.  suggest getting this into master very soon
:+1: after travis
@gianm updated / addressed

I think we can have the best of both worlds here guys.  If we create a filter like

```
{ type: "whereClause",
  "where": "x = billy OR (x = sally and y = 1)" }
```

And then we add a new `QueryRunner` that checks the filter set for instances of the "whereClause" filter and rewrites it into objects like "not", "selector", "bounds", etc. then we can have both worlds.  Downstream logic can be implemented assuming a structured set of objects defining the filter, and we can also support more human-friendly filter statements.
backport ?
test failed from updated unit tests with missing parameters in master. fixed
Cool :+1:

@gianm

so far (1) hasn't been a pain, so reverting to that behavior would be OK for 0.9.0.

(2) would be ideal
(3) and (4) are effectively the same other than whether the event is counted as processed or unparseable, but the row has been added with a subset of aggregators updated. that means data inconsistency. it is probably ok for some user analytics use cases where some errors in numbers is tolerable.
on second thought (1) would be a major pain if/when hit, (4) is probably the best for now if not (2).
@guobingkun since it is just a test I wasn't planning on backporting
@nishantmonu51 can you take a look?
@fjy fixed the test
@drcrallen pushed fix.

would like feedback from at least a couple of @nishantmonu51 @drcrallen @guobingkun @pjain1 or @cheddar on this one, as it is a follow up to https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/druid-development/hfCggehFl_I/INfjEyxbBQAJ and deprecates the feature introduced in #1929.
@b-slim any chance of finishing this up? 0.9.0-rc2 is blocked on it
I prefer (2), but in the interest of moving forward if it takes too long to implement, (4) is cool

@himanshug @fjy do you guys you see a straight forward way to do (2)? I do not see one, and agree (1) is a huge pain if hit, so I am leaning towards (4).

this would cause issues if any aggregators leave themselves in an inconsistent state after parse exceptions, I am not sure how likely this is although my guess is it is not very likely. as my guess is that most aggregators would parse all inputs first and then do something with them after that.

@gianm What if you changed the Aggregator interface to allow:
- Peeking ahead at what the selector would return next
- Aggregating an arbitrary value passed in (not from selector) 

In addToFacts, you could pull all of the next selector values out and validate before facts.putIfAbsent is called

Then use the second aggregating function to feed in the previously read values to the aggs
https://github.com/druid-io/tranquility/pull/126 is the tranquility side of this.
@b-slim I started adding the ability to specify different groups of QTL listeners

About the failing UTs in java8 only.
A list of available column names from a queryable index are turned into a HashMap to get a difference set, as in.
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/segment/QueryableIndexStorageAdapter.java#L92

HashMaps of java7 and java8 are different in ordering elements. But, they are just little hash maps which we should not expect them to order elements though, AFAIK.
@drcrallen ok let me know when u are done, i have some ideas in mind as well !
:+1:  if we can add a UT it will be nice, like that we make sure that the drop won't happen.
@fjy i am think it is good to go unless @drcrallen has a specific UT case in mind.

:+1:, only one minor nit about unused variable.
:+1: after travis

As I replied in the issue page,
user can specify lookup map name within the namespace in `lookup` like

```
{
  "type":"namespace",
  "namepace":"DB1",
  "mapName":"CtoD"
}
```

I added unit test code for explicit Json usage of NamepacedExtraction.
I was able to run this version successfully locally. I'm moving this out of discuss and into review.
